originalTitle: Powerful cyclone kills at least 31 as it tears through Madagascar port
title: Powerful cyclone kills at least 31 as it tears through Madagascar port
content: Madagascar's disaster management says roads are inaccessible with trees uprooted, power poles down and ninety percent of roofs ripped off.

originalTitle: Ghanaians embrace 'Fugu Day' after online mockery of traditional outfits
title: Hooray for Fugu! Ghana's Super Clothes Day!
content:
Hello, Super Friends!

Hi everyone, it's your friendly African news reporter here! I have a super exciting story from a country called Ghana. Ghana is a beautiful country in Africa, just like ours! Imagine a place with lots of sunshine, delicious food, and happy people. Well, in Ghana, something really cool happened that made everyone smile and feel super proud. It’s all about special clothes!

What is Fugu? Let's Find Out!

So, what are these special clothes? They are called Fugu! Can you say Fugu? Foo-goo! Fugu is a very famous and beautiful shirt or top that many people in Ghana wear. It's not just any shirt. It's a traditional outfit. "Traditional" means it's been worn for a very, very long time. It's part of their history and their culture. Imagine your favourite party clothes. Fugu is like that, but even more special! Fugu tops are often made from thick, colourful cotton fabric. They have lovely patterns woven into them. Sometimes they have shiny threads too. People love to wear them for big parties, celebrations, and even just to show off how proud they are of their country. Did you know? The Fugu is sometimes also called a "Batakari." It's mostly worn in the northern part of Ghana. Each colour and pattern on a Fugu can tell a story! How cool is that?

A Little Friendly Fun Online!

Now, something funny happened that made everyone want to wear their Fugu. There was some friendly chatting and joking online. You know, like when you and your friends tease each other, but it's all in good fun? That's what happened between people from Ghana and people from another African country called Zambia. They were talking about clothes on the internet. And some people in Zambia joked about Ghana's traditional Fugu clothes. They said maybe the Fugu looked a bit... old-fashioned. But guess what? Ghanaians didn't get sad or angry! Not at all! They decided to show everyone just how much they love their Fugu! Did you know? Africa has 54 different countries! We are like one big family, and sometimes families tease each other, but they always love each other!

Ghana Says: Hooray for Fugu Day!

So, what did the people in Ghana do? They decided to have a "Fugu Day!" It wasn't an official holiday, but everyone just decided to join in. They said, "We love our Fugu, and we're going to show it off!" And that's exactly what they did. People all over Ghana started wearing their beautiful Fugu outfits. Grandpas, grandmas, mums, dads, aunties, uncles – even some kids! Everyone put on their best Fugu. They wore them to work, to the market, to church, and just around town. They took pictures and shared them online too! It was like a big, colourful parade of pride! People wanted to show the world that their traditional clothes are special and amazing. They wanted to say, "This is who we are, and we are proud!"

Why Are Traditional Clothes So Important?

You might wonder, "Why is wearing old clothes so important?" Well, traditional clothes are like a super special storybook. They tell us about where we come from. They show us the history of our people. When you wear traditional clothes, you are carrying on the traditions of your grand-grandparents! It helps us remember our roots. It helps us feel connected to our family and our country. It makes us feel special and unique. Imagine wearing clothes that your great-great-grandparents also wore! It's like time travel through fabric! Did you know? Many countries in Africa have their own beautiful traditional clothes. In Nigeria, they have Agbada and Ankara. In Kenya, the Maasai wear bright red Shuka wraps. Each one is full of meaning and history!

Kids and Fugu Fun!

Can kids wear Fugu too? YES! Of course! Kids in Ghana also wear smaller versions of the Fugu. Imagine you wearing a colourful Fugu to school or to a birthday party. You would look so smart and proud! When kids wear traditional clothes, it means our culture will stay alive for a long, long time. It means we will always remember where we come from. It's like passing on a secret handshake from one generation to the next!

What This Story Teaches Us

This Fugu story teaches us something very important. It teaches us to be proud! Proud of who we are, proud of where we come from, and proud of our culture. When someone tries to make fun of something special to you, you can show them how much you love it even more! The people of Ghana turned a little bit of online teasing into a big celebration of their heritage. They showed everyone that confidence and pride are very strong. They showed that their culture is beautiful and strong. Did you know? Ghana is famous for its delicious cocoa beans, which are used to make chocolate! Yum! It's also known for its lovely music and friendly people.

Love Your Own Culture!

So, my little friends, what's special about your family or your country? Do you have special clothes? Special dances? Special foods? This story from Ghana reminds us all to love and celebrate our own unique cultures. Don't ever be shy about what makes you, YOU! Be proud like the people of Ghana with their amazing Fugu. Let's all celebrate our beautiful African cultures, together! That's all for today from your African news reporter. See you next time for more happy stories!
summary: People in Ghana showed how much they love their special traditional Fugu clothes after some friendly online jokes!
whyMatters: This story teaches us to be super proud of our own culture and special clothes, just like Ghana is proud of Fugu!

title: Why Frank at Tottenham was a gamble that ended in bitter failure
content: Thomas Frank's sacking came as no surprise on Wednesday. His appointment by Tottenham was a gamble that ended in a storm of toxicity, writes Phil McNulty.

originalTitle: England to play New Zealand and Costa Rica in final World Cup warm-ups
title: England to play New Zealand and Costa Rica in final World Cup warm-ups
content: England will complete their World Cup preparations with matches against New Zealand and Costa Rica in Florida in June, before travelling to their base in Kansas City.
